Tucson first takes a breath with a gentile sigh, as he turns his head to St=
anton and then over to Bump and Torca.

" Well, I'd really love to hear wha=
t you two have to tell us, but, Stantons' right, Rodimus and I have been th=
rough a lot, and perhaps you can tell us another time, when we're more rest=
ed. But I'm sure the others would be interested in hearing your story.  Why=
 don't you tell them, and then catch up to us at a later time perhaps?  Rig=
ht now, I am tired, and I do need rest.  So does Rodimus.  You may use the =
room where Optimus Prime rests, if you wish.  Just be sure to leave things =
as they are."

He says with a gentile voice.  Before becomming a Prime, he =
had been known as gruff autobot, always willing to take chances.  But now, =
his experiences begin to change him, not only on the outside but on the ins=
ide as well.  He had learned a lot in his experience while fighting beside =
Vestige in his subconcious state, and how important team work was, and how =
valuable the help of others truely is.  

" Oh, before you go, Thank you, t=
hank you for standing by us during our ordeal.  It means a lot to us."

---=
 In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, Preston Carroll <supercyclonus@...> wrote:
>
> =
> <OLD>
> >
> > Tucson smiles and puts a hand on Rodimus's shoulder.
> >
> =
> "A favor I would not mind doing for you again, Rodimus. You're worth more=
 to me than any precious metal or power source. And, Torca's right, I - cou=
ld use a rest, but, perhaps I will get that when I undergo the repairs to m=
y optic sensors. Stanton, I need to ask you a favor. One that I know is ext=
remely difficult to accomplish, and one that I'd never ask of you unless it=
 was a dire need. I would like you to attempt the delicate process of bring=
ing my optic sensors back online. If it doesn't work, I understand. But I s=
aw how important it was for me to be able to see in order to get an idea of=
 the situation at hand and how to remedy it. A blind eye can only go so far=
. And if at all possible, could the same be done for Perceptor? He too, des=
erves a second chance of seeing things in a whole new light."
> 
> <NEW>
> =

> Santon nodded, a smile on his face, "I had assumed that you would need
>=
 that sooner or later." He walked over to Tuscon holding a sensors a
> few =
inches from the side of his heard, apparently taking reading, "The
> scanne=
rs should have a pretty good work up on you, but once we get
> this room re=
ady I believe we can get your optics wokring again."
> 
> Bump had walked o=
ver to Rodimus and began running a scanner over him
> as well. "Both of you=
 are to get rest before you go galavanting across
> this planet again. You =
have both been through a lot." Bump looked at
> both of them meaningfuly, i=
t was apparent he was not going to let them
> leave the base withou some re=
charging and true down time.
>

> 
> > "Then my tale has to wait"sa=
id dryly Perceptor.

> Torca had been watching Tuscon and Rodi=
mus with a critical optic as if
> weighing out how much they could handle, =
but he glanced over at
> Perceptor, "No, it does not."
> 
> He looked back =
at Tuscon and then Rodimus, "There are so many tales."
> he said. "We all h=
ave much to discuss."
> 
> "Yes, yes!" Bump said as he glanced up from his =
scanner reading of
> Rodimus, "But not in the medical chamber."
> 
> Torca =
smiled indulgantly at Bump, "Quite right." He looked over at
> Tuscon and R=
odimus, "Shall we take this to another room?"
